action.action-desc: Mr. Cohen (for himself, Mr. Bishop of Georgia, Ms. Lee of California, and Ms. Tlaib) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To prohibit the destruction of civil rights memorials, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Civil Rights Legacy Protection Act.

section.header: Prohibition on destruction of certain property

subsection.text: Chapter 65 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Prohibiting destruction of civil rights memorials

subsection.text: Whoever, in a circumstance described in subsection (b), intentionally defaces, damages, or destroys a protected memorial under subsection (c) or any structure, plaque, statue, or monument on public property that commemorates a covered civil rights event or a covered civil rights figure shall—

paragraph.text: in the case that such defacement, damage, or destruction is in an amount that is equal to or less than $5,000, be required to complete up to 300 hours of community service, fined under this title, or imprisoned not more than a year; or
in the case that such defacement, damage, or destruction is in an amount that is more than $5,000, be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than 3 years.

subsection.text: A circumstance described in this subsection is that—

paragraph.text: in committing the offense described in subsection (a), the defendant travels or causes another to travel in interstate or foreign commerce, or uses the mail or an instrumentality of interstate or foreign commerce; or
the structure, plaque, statue, or monument described in subsection (a) is located on property owned by, or under the jurisdiction of, the Federal Government.

subsection.text: Whoever is convicted of an offense under this section shall be ordered to pay restitution.

paragraph.text: the term covered civil rights figure means any figure on the list submitted by the United States Commission on Civil Rights pursuant to section 3(a) of the Civil Rights Legacy Protection Act; and
the term covered civil rights event means any event on the list submitted by the United States Commission on Civil Rights pursuant to section 3(a) of the Civil Rights Legacy Protection Act.

subsection.text: The table of sections for chapter 65 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following item:

toc.toc-entry: 1370. Prohibiting destruction of civil rights memorials.

section.header: United States Commission on Civil Rights

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the United States Commission on Civil Rights shall develop and submit to the Attorney General a list of covered civil rights events and covered civil rights figures as follows:

paragraph.text: For purposes of developing a list of covered civil rights events, the United States Commission on Civil Rights shall include on the list any event that—

subparagraph.text: memorializes the struggle to secure equal rights for groups suffering from discrimination on the basis of race, religion, disability, gender identity, or sexual orientation during the Civil Rights Movement and other social movements; and
left a positive impression on a unit of local government, a State, or the United States.

paragraph.text: For purposes of developing a list of covered civil rights figures, the United States Commission on Civil Rights shall include on the list any person who—

subparagraph.text: is known for dedication and advocacy toward expanding personal civil liberties and ending racial and other forms of discrimination, disenfranchisement, and segregation; or

clause.text: worked to secure equal rights for groups suffering from discrimination on the basis of race, religion, disability, gender identity, or sexual orientation during the Civil Rights Movement and other social movements; and
has left a positive impression and legacy on a unit of local government, a State, or the United States.

subsection.text: The United States Commission on Civil Rights shall review annually and modify as necessary the list submitted by the Commission pursuant to (a).

The Attorney General shall ensure that the list submitted by the United States Commission on Civil Rights pursuant to subsection (a), and any modifications made by the Commission pursuant to subsection (b), shall be made available to the public on the Department of Justice website.
